title: Can I use my soil pH tester to test the pH of my water? - Quora

response.answer_text: I am not sure what type of pH tester you have. One type has paper strips with different color codes at different pH ranges; when the test area at the bottom of a strip is put in a test solution for a short time and taken out, it takes a color that matches with the coded colors at different pH range in the strip. The other type is pH electrodes that is connected to a pH meter. When the electrode ( after standardizing ) is immersed in a test solution for a short time, its exact pH is shown on the scale of the pH meter. I think you can use either of them to measure pH of water. But you should recognize, pH of pure water is close to neutral; the pH of your test water will depend on the ions it has.

I had my well water tested by a lab. That test yielded a pH of 5.8. Some years later, I tested the water with a cheap kit intended for garden soil. It works by adding a few drops into a transparent vial full of water and comparing the color of the water with a card showing the colors that would correlate with a list of pH values. The pH values on the card did not go below 6.0, but the color of my sample was just slightly different from that of 6.0, so I felt comfortable taking the result from the kit as being pretty darn close to 5.8.

Well, it depends on your meter. Most soil pH’s wont be very extreme so your soil tester might not have the capacity to tell you the whole story. If you are looking for a general sense of the pH, get some indicator strips and read the instructions. Otherwise, get an electrical meter.
